TEI.2.document_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1922: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1928), 3 vols., Vol 2, pp. 595
TEI.2.document_title: J F Madero to John Davis Bradburn, 02-06-1831

barker_notes.barker_summary: José Francisco Madero to Juan Davis Bradburn, February 6, 1831. Explains again fully that the law of April 6, 1830, does not affect his commission. J. Bradburn insists on using force to compel him to suspend work, of course, he must yield. (Omitted.)
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 595

text.body:
*div1 type="summary"* *p*José Francisco Madero to Juan Davis Bradburn, February 6, 1831. Explains again fully that the law of April 6, 1830, does not affect his commission. J. Bradburn insists on using force to compel him to suspend work, of course, he must yield. (Omitted.)*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**location_mentioned*Atascosito*/location_mentioned*, *date_mentioned n="02-06-1831">February 6, 1831*/date_mentioned*.*/p* *p*See Calendar.*/p*
*/div1*
